meta.title: FAQ about COVID-19 School Closures – Longview Public Schools

meta.content:
General FAQ
On Monday, April 6, Governor Inslee ordered all schools (Including the Broadway Learning Center) closed for the remainder of the school year, to help stop the spread of the corona virus. All schools and district facilities will be closed from March 16 until further notice. Remote learning will start on April 15 and

a.span: Dick Mealy Memorial Pool @ Mark Morris

article.class: post-7109 avada_portfolio type-avada_portfolio status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry portfolio_category-fixed

div.class: fusion-fullwidth fullwidth-box fusion-builder-row-1 fusion-ie-mode nonhundred-percent-fullwidth non-hundred-percent-height-scrolling
fusion-layout-column fusion_builder_column fusion_builder_column_1_2 fusion-builder-column-0 fusion-one-half fusion-column-first 1_2

a.span: Why are schools closed, and for how long?

div.p: On Monday, April 6, Governor Inslee ordered all schools (Including the Broadway Learning Center) closed for the remainder of the school year, to help stop the spread of the corona virus. All schools and district facilities will be closed from March 16 until further notice. Remote learning will start on April 15 and continue through June 19.

a.span: Are extracurricular sports and activities canceled?

div.p: Yes, all school sports, activities, clubs, training, athletic practices, events and facilities use are cancelled until further notice. The Broadway Learning Center is also closed.

a.span: Will the district provide instruction through distance learning via the Internet?

div.p: Teacher driven remote learning will start on April 15 and continue through June 19. We posted optional learning resources for students K-12. A link to our Learning Resource page with a list of these learning resources is located below. This page includes a variety of learning resources in English, math, science, social studies and history. Check back regularly for updated resource information.

a.span: Will the school closure impact student testing?

div.p: Yes, the State Office of the Superintendent of Public Instruction (OSPI) has canceled testing for the 2019-20 school year.

a.span: Will the closure impact graduation requirements and when will high school graduation take place?

div.p: As of right now, we are waiting on guidance from the state regarding graduation requirements. Our anticipation is high school seniors will graduate on time. Graduation is planned to remain on June 6, 2020.

a.span: Will the school year be extended?

div.p: Yes, the school year will be extended through June 19, 2020. School will also be in session on the planned May 8 and June 12 snow days.

a.span: Is the school district providing meals for kids in need during the school closure?

div.p: Yes, please click here to see the meal service schedule. Any child, age 0 to 18, will be provided a breakfast and lunch meal served on weekdays.
Meals will continue to be provided during the Stay Home, Stay Healthy order, through Spring Break and throughout the school closure.

a.span: How will Governor Inslee’s request that school districts address the childcare needs of First Responders and Medical Professionals be fulfilled?

div.p: Longview Schools has partnered with Educational Service District 112 (ESD 112) and Childcare Aware to support families of First Responders and medical professionals seeking childcare options.

Visit Childcare Aware at bit.ly/CCAWAOnlineLookup or call the Family Center at 1-800-446-1114 to search for available child care centers during the mandatory school closures due to Covid-19. You will receive an updated list of open child care programs in our area that can meet your child care needs.

a.span: How can I get school district news?

div.p: Stay in touch with school news by visiting longviewschools.com, become a follower on Facebook at facebook.com/longviewschools or sign up for emergency alerts at flashalert.net.

a.span: Is my scheduled school facility and/or field use canceled?

div.p: Yes, all facility use by community members, staff, students and other groups is canceled as of March 16, and will remain closed until further notice.

a.span: Are counseling services available during the school closure?

div.p: Yes, click here to access resources for families and individuals in need.

div.class: fusion-layout-column fusion_builder_column fusion_builder_column_1_2 fusion-builder-column-1 fusion-one-half fusion-column-last 1_2

a.span: How long is my child expected to do school work each day?

div.p: Students are expected to engage in learning activities approximately 11-12 hours each week.

a.span: How will we be informed about the assignments?

div.p: Teachers have been asked to provide families with a weekly learning plan. In some cases, the weekly plan may include suggested daily activities. However, we realize family schedules differ, so there will be flexibility in the weekly learning plan.

a.span: What will remote learning look like for my child?

div.p: There is no single model for remote learning. Some teachers will conduct classes through Zoom or Google Hangouts, where teachers and students interact. Other teachers will post online videos, activities, and assignments in an online platform such as Google classroom. Other teachers will have students do work in a print workbook or packet, providing help as needed. The one constant is that teachers are committed to helping students continue learning during this time of school closure.

a.span: What should I do if my child has trouble doing the assignments?

div.p: Frequent communication between teachers and families is very important. Teachers will work with each family to figure out the best method for providing support with student learning. Families should reach out to the teacher with questions or requests for help.
If your question is not listed above, please email infoteam@longviewschools.org.
